# Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (TSM) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Limited (TSMC), together with its subsidiaries, manufactures, packages, tests, and sells integrated circuits and other semiconductor devices globally. TSMC pioneered the pure-play foundry business model when it was founded in 1987, and has been the world's leading dedicated semiconductor foundry ever since, supporting a thriving ecosystem of global customers and partners. TSMC deployed 288 distinct process technologies and manufactured 11,878 products for 522 customers in 2024. The company is the world's largest dedicated contract chip manufacturer with mid-60s market share in 2024.

The company provides various wafer fabrication processes, including complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) logic, mixed-signal, radio frequency, embedded memory, and bipolar CMOS mixed-signal processes, along with customer and engineering support services, mask manufacturing, technology start-up investments, and advanced packaging solutions.

## 2. Current Market Data

As of January 11, 2026, TSM is trading at approximately $318-$324, with the current stock price at $323.63. The stock has a 52-week range of $134.25 to $333.08, with the 52-week high reached on January 6, 2026. Market capitalization stands at $1.65 trillion as of January 9, 2026. According to 4 analysts, the average rating for TSM stock is "Strong Buy" with a 12-month stock price target of $361.25, representing an 11.62% increase from current levels.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

TSMC operates as a pure-play foundry, offering:

• **Advanced Process Technologies**: N7+ (first commercially available EUV process with 15-20% higher transistor density), N5 (doubles transistor density with 15% performance improvement), and N3 (provides 70% increase in logic density and 15% speed improvement over 5nm).

• **Manufacturing Facilities**: Annual capacity of approximately 17 million 12-inch equivalent wafers across multiple facilities in Taiwan, plus subsidiaries in Arizona, Japan, China, and Washington.

• **Advanced Packaging**: CoWoS (Chip on Wafer on Substrate) packaging technology that enhances AI chip performance through tighter integration of multiple dies.

• **Specialty Technologies**: Process technology, special process technology, design ecosystem support, mask technology, and 3DFabric advanced packaging services.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

**2nm Technology Rollout**: TSMC has officially commenced mass production of its 2-nanometer (N2) chips at Fab 22 in Kaohsiung, making it the only foundry capable of delivering these ultra-advanced processors at high volumes as of January 2, 2026. 2nm monthly capacity is expected to reach 40,000 wafers by end-2025, expanding to 80,000-90,000 wafers by end-2026, with revenue from 2nm consumables potentially matching today's 3nm levels by 2027-2028.

**Enhanced 2nm Variants**: Later in 2026, TSMC plans to introduce N2P, an enhanced version featuring backside power delivery technology, serving as a bridge to the A16 (1.6nm) node slated for mass production in 2027.

**Advanced Packaging Expansion**: TSMC is scaling CoWoS capacity from approximately 35,000 wafers per month in late 2024 to a projected 130,000 wafers per month by end-2026.

## 5. Growth Strategy

TSMC's growth strategy centers on maintaining technology leadership while expanding globally:

**Global Manufacturing Expansion**: TSMC announced plans to build a third fab at TSMC Arizona to meet customer demand, with the facility producing chips using 2nm or more advanced processes. Plans to expand Arizona campus from six to twelve fabs with advanced packaging capacity increasing from two to three or four facilities.

**Technology Roadmap**: TSMC's 2nm technology leads the industry, with N2 process on track for volume production in second half of 2025, and A16 featuring backside power delivery scheduled for second half of 2026.

**Capital Investment**: TSMC's 2026 CapEx is expected to reach $50 billion, driven by strong AI demand, compared to $40-42 billion in 2025.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

**Top Customers by Revenue Share (2025 projections)**:
- Apple (25%), NVIDIA (11%), MediaTek (9%), Qualcomm (8%), AMD (7%), Broadcom (7%), and Intel (6%)

**2026 Projected Changes**: Apple (22-25%), Broadcom (11-15%), NVIDIA (11%), MediaTek (9-10%), Qualcomm (8%), AMD (7%), and Intel (7%)

**Key Partnerships**: Apple conducting limited trial production of SoIC technology with mass production anticipated between 2025-2026, while NVIDIA and Broadcom are collaborating on SoIC development.

## 7. Financial Data & Performance

**2024 Financial Results**: Net income was NT$1,173.27 billion with diluted EPS of NT$45.25, both increasing 39.9% from 2023. In USD terms, TSMC generated net income of $36.52 billion on revenue of $90.08 billion, up 35.9% and 30.0% respectively.

**Q4 2025 Performance**: Q4 2025 revenue totaled NT$1.046 trillion (~$33.1 billion), up more than 20% year-over-year, driven by strong demand for AI and high-performance computing chips.

**Profitability Metrics**: 2024 gross profit margin was 56.1% vs 54.4% in 2023, operating profit margin was 45.7% vs 42.6%, and net profit margin was 40.5% vs 38.8%.

## 8. Market Shares

**Foundry Market Dominance**: TSMC controlled 68% of global semiconductor foundry revenue by end-2024. TSMC maintained 67.6% market share in Q1 2025.

**Advanced Nodes**: Advanced technologies (7nm and below) accounted for 74% of wafer revenue, with advanced nodes generating roughly 74% of wafer revenue.

**Global Market Position**: According to industry estimates, TSMC controls about 70% of the global contract chip manufacturing market.

## 9. Comparison to Competitors

**Samsung**: Samsung holds 12% market share in Q3 2024 but fell to 7.7% in Q1 2025, struggling with yield issues and limited exposure to China's consumer benefits.

**Intel**: Intel is conspicuous in its absence from TSMC's 2nm customer list, currently using TSMC 3nm for compute tiles while developing in-house Intel 18A foundry node.

**GlobalFoundries**: GlobalFoundries' market share declined from 8% to 4%, with revenue down 13.9% to $1.58 billion due to seasonal weakness.

## 10. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

**Japan Expansion**: TSMC and Sony announced Japan Advanced Semiconductor Manufacturing (JASM) in Kumamoto, with the first factory beginning commercial operations in December 2024 producing 12-, 22-, and 28-nanometer processes.

**European Partnership**: TSMC's Germany plant is a joint venture with Bosch, Infineon, and NXP, focusing on 16/12-nanometer and 28/22-nanometer specialty processes for automotive applications.

**Advanced Packaging Collaborations**: Major clients including AMD, Apple, NVIDIA, and Broadcom are collaborating on SoIC technology development, with AMD already implementing SoIC in production.

## 11. Recent Developments

**Export License**: The U.S. government granted TSMC an annual license to import U.S. chip manufacturing equipment to its facilities in Nanjing, China, ensuring uninterrupted operations.

**Trade Secret Issues**: In August 2025, TSMC reported that eight employees illegally acquired trade secrets related to the 2nm process, with several arrests by Taiwanese authorities.

**Capacity Expansion**: TSMC acquired Innolux Tainan 4th plant for NT$17 billion, designated as AP8, which will become the 7th advanced packaging plant with production starting in second half 2025.

**Q4 2025 Earnings**: TSMC's Fourth Quarter 2025 Earnings Conference is scheduled for January 15, 2026, during which detailed guidance will be provided.

## 12. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

**Investment Strengths**:
• **Technological Moat**: TSMC is the only foundry capable of high-volume 2nm production, creating a strategic advantage that competitors like Intel and Samsung cannot easily overcome.
• **AI Market Positioning**: NVIDIA secured over 60% of TSMC's CoWoS capacity for 2025-2026, demonstrating TSMC's critical role in AI infrastructure.
• **Pricing Power**: 2nm capacity for 2026 is "completely sold out," allowing TSMC to implement 3-10% price increases across advanced nodes.

**Growth Catalysts**:
• **2nm Ramp**: Bulls expect 2026 revenue growth north of 25%, with Apple securing initial 2nm output for A20 and M5 chips.
• **CoWoS Expansion**: Resolution of packaging bottlenecks that defined 2024-2025 clears the way for massive AI hardware influx.

**Risk Factors**:
• **Geopolitical Exposure**: Taiwan concentration remains a key risk despite global expansion efforts
• **High CapEx**: Capital expenditures projected to rise from $40-42 billion in 2025 to potentially $50+ billion in 2027-2028.
• **Overseas Margin Pressure**: Gross margins expected to shrink 2-3% in 2025 due to Arizona and Japan fab ramp-up.

**AI Investment Rating: 9/10**

TSMC represents the quintessential AI infrastructure play with unmatched technology leadership, dominant market position, and exclusive access to the most advanced manufacturing processes. The company's 2nm technology leadership and CoWoS capacity expansion directly enable the AI revolution.

**Fair Value Assessment: $355-$375**

Based on Wall Street's consensus $355 target representing 20%+ upside, combined with TSMC's expanding technology moat, AI-driven demand acceleration, and pricing power from sold-out advanced capacity, a fair value range of $355-$375 appears justified for growth-oriented investors with moderate risk tolerance. The premium valuation reflects TSMC's indispensable role in the global technology ecosystem and its position as the primary beneficiary of AI infrastructure buildout through 2027.
